paragraphs.text: At Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics our team puts patients first. We deliver personalized orthodontic care for children, teens, and adults using modern digital tools and an approachable, family-friendly office atmosphere.

We combine advanced treatment planning, flexible financing options, and attentive patient support so your orthodontic journey is comfortable and straightforward. Call (618) 400-0900 or request a consultation online to get started.

items.title: Patient-First Care
items.text: We treat every patient with care and clear communication so families feel comfortable at every visit.

items.title: Advanced Technology
items.text: We use digital scans and modern planning tools to make treatment more predictable and comfortable.

items.title: Flexible Financing
items.text: Affordable plans and clear payment options help make great orthodontic care easy to access.

paragraphs.text: Meet Dr. Jodi Hentscher-Johnson, a board certified orthodontist who has been transforming smiles since 2012. Passionate about blending art and science, she loves building genuine connections with patients and making every visit enjoyable. Dr. Jodi is dedicated to using the latest technology and techniques to ensure your treatment is more comfortable, efficient, and effective. Outside the office, she supports local women’s organizations and chambers of commerce and enjoys time with her family.

Meet Dr. Taylor Little, an orthodontist passionate about providing personalized, accessible, and enjoyable care for every patient. She focuses on evidence-based treatment and advanced technology, with special interests in laser gingivectomy, TADs, and care for patients with special needs. Dr. Little is committed to continual learning and delivering confident smiles that last a lifetime.
We offer a full range of orthodontic services, including braces, clear aligners, retainers, and early treatment to help patients of all ages achieve healthy, confident smiles.

og_meta.description: Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics provides patient-first orthodontic care with braces, clear aligners, and retainers. Call (618) 400-0900 to schedule a consult.

image.alt: Orthodontic team smiling in a bright office lobby

paragraphs.text: At HJO, we’re all about fun. We create a positive, stress-free atmosphere where our energetic team puts patients first and makes every visit welcoming for kids and adults alike.
We use the latest technology, like 3D printing for in-house aligners and CBCT scans for ultra-precise imaging, to keep treatment efficient, accurate, and comfortable for every patient.

We love giving back to our community through events, school visits, and local sponsorships. Our flexible payment plans and no-interest financing options are designed to make orthodontic care more accessible.
By combining modern tools, proven techniques, and a patient-first approach, we help patients of all ages reach confident, healthy smiles with care that fits their lives.

I really enjoy practicing orthodontics. I find a lot of satisfaction in creating smiles, and enjoy showing my patients how much progress they’re making and how their efforts are paying off. Seeing their happiness at the end of treatment never grows old.

The combination of science, art and hands-on care required in orthodontics is very rewarding. I started working for my own orthodontist in 11th grade and later worked in orthodontic labs to pay my way through college, which solidified my commitment to the specialty.

image.alt: Dr. Jared Gill in clinical setting

paragraphs.text: Undergraduate degree – Utah State University. Doctorate of Dental Medicine – Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland. Orthodontic specialty – St. Barnabas Hospital, New York. I regularly attend orthodontic and dental meetings to stay current with the latest treatment options and technology.

I live in West Fargo with my wife Katie and our four children. When I’m not working, you’ll find me reading, fishing, gardening, riding my bike, and playing video games with my kids. I’m active in my kids’ schools and participate regularly in my church.

Meet Dr. Jodi Hentscher-Johnson, a board certified orthodontist transforming smiles since 2012. She blends art and science to deliver care that’s comfortable and effective, and she takes pride in building genuine connections with patients.
Dr. Jodi earned her dental and specialty training before becoming board certified. She focuses on modern techniques and technology to keep treatment comfortable and efficient.

A proud Red Bud native, Dr. Jodi lives in Columbia with her family and two dogs. She enjoys spending time at the Lake of the Ozarks and cheering on St. Louis teams, and she is active in local women’s organizations and chambers of commerce.
Dr. Little is dedicated to personalized, accessible orthodontic care. She uses evidence-based treatment and advanced technology to create confident smiles while keeping patient comfort front of mind.

Dr. Little pursues continuing education and has special interests in laser gingivectomy, TADs, and providing care for patients with special needs, using the latest tools and techniques to tailor treatment plans.
Originally from the St. Louis area, Dr. Little enjoys nature, local coffee shops, cheering on her favorite teams, and spending time with her husband Jon and their corgi and cat.

image.alt: Smiling family welcomed at Lakeshore Orthodontics front desk

paragraphs.text: At Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics, your first visit is a warm, informative appointment where we get to know you and your smile goals. Expect a friendly welcome, a complete exam, and a clear discussion of treatment options so you leave with a straightforward plan and next steps.

We’ll review your medical history, answer questions about financing and insurance, and explain what to expect during treatment. Our team is focused on comfort and clarity, and we’ll make sure you feel like part of the HJO family from day one.

image.alt: Father with daughter at reception of dentist's surgery

paragraphs.text: We accept most major insurance plans and will file claims electronically to make coverage simple and convenient.
Flexible payment plans and no-interest financing options are available. Our treatment coordinator will work with you to find an option that fits your budget.

Before your appointment, please complete our health history forms so we can provide safe, personalized care. Completing forms ahead of time helps your visit run smoothly and lets us focus on your exam.

image.alt: Patient filling out orthodontic health history forms online

seo.page_description: Request a complimentary consultation at Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics. Learn what to expect, complete forms, and book your free consult today.
seo.page_keywords: Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics, complimentary consultation, new patient, virtual consult, financing

og_meta.title: Get Started | Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics
og_meta.description: Request a complimentary consultation at Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics. Learn what to expect, complete forms, and book your free consult today.

image.alt: Adult and child smiling after orthodontic treatment at Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics

paragraphs.text: Orthodontic braces correct bite and tooth alignment for children, teens and adults. Beyond a straighter smile, treatment can improve chewing, speech and long-term dental health while preventing excessive wear and jaw strain.
Anyone with crowding, spacing, overbite, underbite or crossbite may benefit. We evaluate each patient with X-rays and study models to recommend the best approach.

image.alt: Teen patient after receiving orthodontic care

paragraphs.text: Straight teeth are easier to clean and less likely to develop decay or gum disease. Orthodontics can also relieve jaw pain and improve function.

image.alt: Adult patient smiling after orthodontic treatment

paragraphs.text: Your journey begins with a planning phase: exam, photographs, impressions or digital scans and X-rays. From there we design a personalized plan and discuss timelines and options.

image.alt: Hentscher-Johnson Orthodontics team in the office

paragraphs.text: Metal braces use brackets and archwires to apply gentle, continuous pressure that moves teeth into position. Adjustments are scheduled regularly to monitor progress.
Durable and effective for complex cases, metal braces often achieve results faster and are cost-effective compared with other fixed options.
Ceramic braces offer a discreet option with tooth-colored brackets that blend in. They work much like traditional braces while providing improved aesthetics during treatment.
These brackets can be slightly more fragile and may stain if not cared for, so we provide clear guidance on cleaning and dietary choices to protect their appearance.

image.alt: Clear aligner and tooth-colored braces icon

paragraphs.text: Invisalign<sup>®</sup> and other clear aligner systems use a series of removable, transparent trays to move teeth discreetly. They are ideal for many adult and teen cases where compliance is reliable.
Because aligners are removable, you can maintain normal brushing, flossing and eating. Treatment starts with a digital scan and 3D planning so you can see projected results before treatment begins.

image.alt: Close-up of clear aligners and patient smile

paragraphs.text: Angel Aligners are a digitally planned, removable tray system that combines precise 3D scanning with predictable staging to move teeth comfortably and discreetly.
At our practice we evaluate candidacy carefully and discuss whether in-house printed aligners or an external aligner system is the best fit for your goals and lifestyle.

image.alt: Orthodontic team discussing clear aligner treatment

paragraphs.text: Lingual braces are placed on the tongue side of the teeth, making them invisible from the front. They offer a concealment option for patients who need fixed appliances but want a discreet look.
Lingual braces provide excellent aesthetics but can be more costly and may require a short adjustment period for speech and comfort.
Not all cases are suited to lingual braces. We review bite complexity, oral anatomy and lifestyle to determine suitability.
Oral hygiene and routine check-ups are essential. We provide clear instructions to keep brackets and appliances clean throughout treatment.
Retention is a critical final phase. Custom retainers help stabilize tooth position while bone and soft tissues remodel, protecting the time and investment you made during active treatment.
We offer removable and fixed retainer options and give clear guidance on how long and how often to wear them to reduce the risk of relapse.

image.alt: Orthodontic retainer being held by a patient

paragraphs.text: We take airway health seriously, particularly for growing patients. Early assessment and monitoring can identify risks like mouth breathing or sleep-disordered breathing and guide timely, conservative intervention.

image.alt: Airway assessment icon showing facial profile and airflow

image.alt: Patient smiling with orthodontic braces in our Emeryville office

paragraphs.text:
Below are some of the most frequently asked questions patients have about orthodontics. If you have any other questions, or would like to schedule an appointment, we would love to hear from you.

Click on a question below to see the answer.

accordion.header: How often should I brush and floss?

paragraphs.text:
Brushing and flossing control the plaque and bacteria that cause decay and gum disease. Plaque is a film of food debris, bacteria, and saliva that sticks to teeth and gums; if not removed it hardens into calculus. Plaque and calculus can destroy gum and bone over time.

Toothbrushing: Brush at least twice a day, especially before bed, with an ADA-approved soft-bristle brush and fluoride toothpaste. Hold the brush at a 45 degree angle to the gums and use small, gentle circular motions. Clean outer, inner, and biting surfaces, use the brush tip for inside front teeth, and brush your tongue to reduce bacteria and freshen breath. Electric toothbrushes are recommended; let the brush do the work, moving it across several teeth at a time.

Flossing: Floss daily to clean between teeth and under the gumline. Use 12–16 inches (30–40 cm) of floss, wrap it around your fingers, and guide it gently between teeth. Curve the floss into a C shape around each tooth and move it up and down to clean the sides and under the gumline. Floss holders are helpful for those who find traditional floss difficult.

Rinsing: Rinse with water after brushing and after meals when brushing isn’t possible. If using an over-the-counter rinse, ask your dentist or hygienist if it’s appropriate for you.

accordion.header: At what age should my child be checked by an orthodontist?

paragraphs.text: The American Association of Orthodontists recommends an orthodontic evaluation no later than age 7. Early evaluation lets us monitor growth and development and plan treatment when it will be most effective.

accordion.header: How often should I have a dental exam and cleaning?

paragraphs.text: Have your teeth checked and cleaned at least twice a year, unless your dentist or hygienist recommends more frequent visits based on your individual needs.

accordion.header: How long will I be in braces?

paragraphs.text: Treatment time varies with the severity of the case, patient cooperation, and growth. Some cases finish in less than a year, while more complex cases take longer. On average treatment can take two to three years; we’ll give a personalized estimate at your initial appointment and aim to reduce visits while maintaining excellent results.

accordion.header: What do I need to consider when using a retainer?

paragraphs.text: Proper use and care of your retainer preserves your new alignment. Don’t lose the appliance: keep removable retainers in their case while eating, drinking, and brushing. Don’t drink or eat while wearing a retainer, as trapped liquids and food increase decay risk and can damage the device. Clean retainers thoroughly: Hawley retainers can be brushed with a toothbrush, and VFR (PVC) retainers should be cleaned with denture cleaner or a specialized retainer cleaner. Wear the retainer as directed—retention lets bone, tissue, and muscles stabilize teeth after braces; failure to wear it can allow movement back to the original position.
